School of Resources and Environmental Engineering Jiangsu University of Technology Changzhou Jiangsu 213001 PR China 1 The authors contribute the same and are co-first authors The Pt-based catalyst for purifying chlorinated volatile organic compounds (Cl-VOCs) has the advantages of high catalytic efficiency and low ignition temperature, but the problem of poor resistance to chlorine and water poisoning has not been effectively solved. A series of 0.5 Pt-Ti catalysts were prepared for chlorobenzene (CB) catalytic oxidation by adjusting the interfacial stability and dispersibility of the TiO2 and Pt through the organic acid strategy in this study. The introduction of tartaric acid (TA) effectively enhanced the surface reduction performance of 0.5Pt-Ti-TA and the proportion of Pt4+ on the surface. In addition, TA can strongly coordinate with Ti center to form stable titanium-containing complexes, improve the dispersion of Pt, prevent particles from agglomerating, and make the distribution of active sites more uniform. The designed 0.5Pt-Ti-TA exhibits excellent chlorine and water resistance at 300℃ (5 %H2O, 500 ppm CB), and has a higher potential of application. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Chlorobenzene Catalytic oxidation Active Pt Organic acid Metal dispersion Data availability The data that has been used is confidential. 1 Introduction Chlorinated volatile organic compounds (Cl-VOCs) is widely used in industry, agriculture, medicine and other fields [1,2]. However, with the rapid development of industry, the emission of Cl-VOCs has gradually increased, and there is lasting pollution and harm to environmental safety and human health [3,4]. In addition, Cl-VOCs tend to condense with other organic pollutants at high temperatures, producing more toxic chlorine-containing by-products such as PCDFs (polychlorinated dibenzofurans) and PCDDs (polychlorinated dibenzo-p-dioxins) [5]. In order to complete the "14th Five-Year Plan" VOCs emissions reduction task of 10 %. Developing core technology for the efficient decontamination of Cl-VOCs and effectively controlling pollutants represented by chlorobenzene (CB) holds great significance for improving the quality of human living environment. VOCs removal technologies mainly include biodegradation, photocatalysis, catalytic oxidation, plasma catalysis, etc. [6–8]. Among them, catalytic oxidation technology can convert VOCs into CO2 and H2O without producing other harmful substances [9]. Addition, catalytic oxidation technology has significant advantages of low cost, high efficiency, good stability, wide range of application and no secondary pollution, and has broad application prospects in Cl-VOCs control [10]. At present, there are two main catalysts for catalytic oxidation of Cl-VOCs [11] (noble metal catalysts and non-precious metal catalysts). Previously, we have conducted a series of studies on manganese-based catalysts and coated Pt-based catalysts [12,13]. Among them, non-precious metal catalysts have low cost and good toxicity resistance, but their short service life and low catalytic activity limit large-scale application in industrial production [14]. In contrast, noble metal catalysts (Pd, Pt, Au) have the potential for large-scale industrial application due to low ignition temperature, fast activity rise and high catalytic efficiency [15]. Ren et al. [16] found that Pt is an excellent active element for aromatic structure oxidation among many precious metals, and noble metal-based catalysts dominated by Pt-based catalysts exhibit excellent low-temperature catalytic activity against Cl-VOCs, but the high cost, limited reserves, easy sintering at high temperatures, and poor anti-poisoning ability of Pt limit its wide application [17,18]. Therefore, the development of novel catalysts featuring low Pt loading, high stability, and resistance to toxicity holds significant importance for practical production, environmental control, and the adjustment of energy structures. The carrier type of supported catalyst has significant influence on the release of catalyst activity. The selection of a suitable support can strengthen catalytic activity, effectively suppress the aggregation and sintering of metal particles, and consequently enhance the anti-poisoning capability and thermal stability. Studies have shown that nanostructured titanium dioxide (TiO2) exhibits both Lewis acidity and redox properties, and surface acid sites are the effective adsorption centers of Cl-VOCs [1], which is conducive to the catalytic oxidation of Cl-VOCs, and its advantages such as large specific surface area, unique pore structure, and good heat resistance have great potential application value in the field of environment and energy and have been widely studied. Zhang et al. [19] prepared a Pt/TiO2 catalyst supported on TiO2 nanorods, and successfully increased the specific surface area of TiO2 to 304 m2/g, and the conversion rate of the catalyst in benzyl alcohol photocatalytic oxidation was 32.2 %. At the same time, Sun et al. [20] discovered that toluene undergoes an early oxidative dehydrogenation reaction with reactive oxygen species, attributed to the high activity at the Pt-TiO2 interface. The resulting substances are subsequently strongly adsorbed onto the active sites, thereby causing catalyst poisoning and impeding further oxidation. Cao et al. [21]found that the Pt/TiO2 catalyst had poor decomposition ability to DCM (Cl2CH2), which was mainly due to the deposition of carbon covering the active site of DCM decomposition, and on the other hand, the reaction between the Cl species and the active components of the catalyst led to the poor anti-poisoning ability of the Pt-based catalyst and accelerated the inactivation of the Pt/TiO2. This further indicates that the anti-poisoning ability of the above-mentioned Pt-based catalysts still needs to be improved. According to relevant reports, organic acids, as low-cost compounds containing carboxyl groups at the end, can be used as chelating agents-assisted catalysts for the preparation [22], and the organic acid-assisted catalysts can promote the interface binding between Pt and the support in the process of preparation, and are also conducive to the improvement of catalyst activity and stability. Li et al. [23] found that the dispersion of the catalyst can be improved by oxalic acid and citric acid, the particle size of Pt can be effectively reduced, the reaction area can be increased, and the stability is good, which is conducive to the efficient conversion of CO2 by Pt-based catalysts. Cao et al. [24] used organic acid-assisted impregnation method to prepare Pt-based catalysts, and found that citric acid-assisted preparation could not only improve the dispersion of Pt, but also promote the interaction between metal Pt sites and supports while changing the concentration of Lewis acid sites, which had the best propane dehydrogenation performance and good stability. Therefore, the preparation strategy of organic acid-assisted catalysts offers a novel design approach for novel materials exhibiting high dispersion and superior stability. In this study, a catalyst was developed that exhibits good thermal stability and strong resistance to chlorine toxicity, while incorporating a low Pt loading. Multiple organic acids were employed as chelating agents in the preparation of a series of Pt-based materials with varying loading amounts via the impregnation technique. Subsequently, the surface characteristic of the catalysts was analyzed using XRD, SEM, and BET. Subsequently, gas chromatography was employed to ascertain the oxidation of CB under varying Pt loadings and diverse organic acid chelators in Pt-based catalysts. Moreover, XPS technology was used to delve into the chemical valence change of Pt of organic acid-assisted preparation of Pt-based catalysts, and the influences of organic acids on the physicochemical attributes of the catalysts were investigated. Through the aforementioned research, it was anticipated that novel comprehension and solutions could be provided for the treatment of CB. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials The reagents used in this paper are analytical grade reagents, including chloroplatinic acid (H2PtCl6·6H2O, Pt≥37.5 %) (McLean, China), citric acid (C6H8O7, 99 % purity) (Aladdin, China), tartaric acid (C4H6O6, 99 % purity) (Sigma-Aldrich, Germany), oxalic acid (H2C2O4, 99 % purity) (Merck, Germany), alumina (Al2O3, 99 % purity) (Thermo Fisher, United States), silicon dioxide (SiO2, 99 %) (Comieu, China), calcium oxide (CaO, 99 %) (McCarthy, China), nano titanium dioxide (TiO2, 99.9 %) (Aladdin, China). 2.2 Catalyst preparation The details are in the supporting information. 2.3 Characterization of catalysts A battery of characterization techniques, including XRD, SEM, TEM, BET, Raman, ICP-AES, H2-TPR, and XPS, were employed to investigate the structure and surface physicochemical properties of the synthesized catalyst. Detailed information can be found in the supporting information. 2.4 Performance evaluation of catalysts The details are in the supporting information. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Combustion performance of CB As shown in Fig. 1 , parameters of CB oxidation under the same conditions were investigated and compared between the Pt-based catalyst and the catalyst without Pt components. In Fig. 1a and b, oxidation capacity of CB is significantly improved at high temperatures. Compared with the catalyst without Pt component, the effect of 0.5Pt-Ti and 0.5Pt-Al in catalyzing the oxidation of CB was more significant, and the CO2 selectivity was also higher, indicating that the addition of Pt was conducive to improving the conversion rate of CB, mainly due to the interaction between Pt and the support to enhance the electron transfer [25]. Thereby improving the catalytic activity of CB, but the conversion rate of CB decreased after the CaO support was loaded with Pt, mainly due to the low dispersion of Pt particles caused by CaO [5]. The failure to effectively disperse Pt particles leads to the agglomeration of Pt particles on the surface of the catalyst, which affects the activity and stability of the catalyst, reducing CB conversion and CO2 selectivity [26]. Fig. S1 illustrates the combustion of CB and the selectivity of CO2 when three distinct organic acids are introduced to the 0.5 % Pt-based catalyst. The graph distinctly demonstrates that both the removal rate of CB and the selectivity of CO2 progressively increase with rising temperature. In Fig. S1a and Fig. S1c, it can be observed that the degradation effect of CB is significant with 0.5Pt-Al-CA and 0.5Pt-Ti-TA catalysts. This may be attributed to the complexation of the chelating agent with Pt ions during catalyst preparation [27], which increases the dispersion of the metal and exposes more active sites. It is beneficial to the adsorption and activation of oxygen molecules, resulting in an increase in the content of oxygen adsorbed on the surface [28]. Fig. S2 illustrates the temperatures required for the 0.5Pt-Al, 0.5Pt-Al-CA, 0.5Pt-Ti, and 0.5Pt-Ti-TA catalysts to achieve CB conversion of 90 % and 50 %. As can be observed from Fig. S2a, the T50 of the catalyst after the addition of organic acids (0.5Pt-Al-CA and 0.5Pt-Ti-TA) is higher than that of the catalyst without the addition of organic acids (0.5Pt-Al and 0.5Pt-Ti), which may be due to the adsorption of organic acids, which forms a covering on the surface of the catalyst, reducing the exposure of the catalyst active site [29], thus requiring a higher temperature to activate the reaction. However, it is observed from Fig. S2b that the T90 of the catalyst after the addition of organic acids is lower than that of the catalyst without organic acids, which may be due to the fact that the introduction of chelating agent in the preparation process changes the surface acidity of the catalyst, enhances the interaction between Pt and the support [16], and is conducive to improving the catalytic efficiency of CB, which in turn leads to the reduction of the T90 of 0.5Pt-Al-CA and 0.5Pt-Ti-TA. In addition, it can be found from Fig.S2 that the T50 and T90 of 0.5Pt-Ti and 0.5Pt-Ti-TA catalysts are lower than those of both 0.5Pt-Al and 0.5Pt-Al-CA catalysts, indicating that 0.5Pt-Ti-TA catalyst has higher catalytic efficiency. The tartaric acid, as a typical α-hydroxycarboxylic acid, can have a strong coordination with the Ti center [30], thereby improving the overall performance of the catalyst. In view of the poor resistance of precious metal catalysts to chlorine poisoning, it is further explored sustainable oxidation and water resistance of Pt-Al-CA and Pt-Ti-TA materials loaded with varying Pt concentrations for the long-term degradation of CB (WHSV: 30,000 mL·g-1·h-1). The stability and water resistance of the catalytic oxidation of CB were further examined (Fig. 2 and Fig. S3). The long-term stability of the catalysts (0.5Pt-Al-OA, 0.5Pt-Al-CA, 0.5Pt-Al-TA, 0.5Pt-Al) was assessed under the conditions of a reaction temperature of 340 °C. The removal rate of 0.5 Pt-Al-OA, 0.5 Pt-Al-CA and 0.5 Pt-Al-TA to CB slowly drops to about 87 % and tends to be stable, while the oxidation performance of 0.5Pt-Al catalyst is only about 60 %. The above results indicate that organic acids can effectively regulate the Pt activity on the carrier surface to alleviate the Cl poisoning process. Considering that the introduction of organic acids during catalyst preparation may result in partial dissolution of the support, the metal content in different catalysts was tested by ICP-AES (Table S1). The results show that the actual Al content in the catalyst is significantly lower than the theoretical content after the introduction of tartaric acid, which may be because the addition of tartaric acid will lead to the dissolution of part Al2O3, resulting in the reduction of Al content in the obtained catalyst. The introduction of organic acid to prepare 0.5Pt-Ti series catalysts did not significantly reduce the metal content. In addition, based on the high oxidation activity of 0.5Pt-Ti catalyst on CB, the study further tested the stability and water resistance of 0.5Pt-Ti-OA, 0.5Pt-Ti-CA, 0.5Pt-Ti-TA three catalysts (Fig. S3). At a high reaction temperature of 340℃, the four materials not only have stable oxidation ability to CB, but also have excellent water resistance, which confirms the good stability of the designed materials. In order to further verify the low-temperature catalytic ability of Pt-Al-CA and Pt-Ti-TA, a low temperature catalytic experiment was designed at 300℃ to study the anti-toxic ability of the site of oxidation on the surface of the material to Cl and water molecules. In Fig. S3b, the catalytic activity of Pt-Al-CA materials decreased overall, indicating that reaction temperature had a significant impact on Cl poisoning and water resistance. The low-temperature combustion performance and water resistance of the Pt-Ti-TA catalysts suggest that TA exerts a significant influence on the enhancement of Pt activity (Fig. 2b and Fig. 3 ). It is possible that the organic acid enhances the low-temperature catalytic ability of the catalyst by elevating the Pt activity on the surface of the carrier. In Fig .S4, it can be found that the catalyst prepared by organic acid chelating Pt showed excellent catalytic activity of toluene at low temperature (T90 < 230℃), confirming that the developed catalyst has the oxidation ability of various VOCs and can be applied in complex exhaust gas environment. In addition, the CB oxidation performance of 0.5Pt-Ti-TA was tested under different weight hourly space velocity (WHSV, Fig. 4 ), and the results showed that the increase of WHSV would affect the catalytic performance of CB, which may be due to the high WHSV leading to the adsorption process and being affected, and the incomplete oxidation products leading to the failure to release the active site. 3.2 Structure and surface characteristic of 0.5Pt-Ti-TA catalyst The structure of the catalyst was analyzed by XRD (Fig. 5 ). The two catalysts prepared have similar characteristic diffraction peaks. The diffraction peaks at 25.3°, 37.7°, 48.0°, 53.8°, 55.0°, 62.6°, 68.6°, 70.2° and 74.9° correspond to the (101), (004), (200), (105), (211), (116), (220) and (215) planes of anatase TiO2, which are consistent with the XRD standard card of pure anatase TiO2 in the literature (JCPDS NO.21–1272) [31]. It can be seen that the introduction of tartaric acid did not affect the crystal structure of the sample before and after doping, and also showed that tartaric acid, as a typical α-hydroxycarboxylic acid, can have a strong coordination with the Ti center, and the steric hindrance effect of the carboxyl group is more conducive to the formation of anatase, so as to form a stable titanium-containing complex [19]. At the same time, the characteristic diffraction peak of Pt was not clearly observed in the figure, indicating that the Pt particles were small and highly dispersed on the surface of the support [32]. To acquire microscopic morphological, scanning electron microscopy (SEM) analysis was conducted on 0.5Pt-Ti and 0.5Pt-Ti-TA (Fig. 6 ). Compared with the Pt-based catalyst with TA (Fig. 6 g-i), it can be seen that the morphology of 0.5Pt-Ti-TA and 0.5Pt-Ti catalyst has similar morphology, indicating that the morphology of TiO2 remains basically unchanged after the reduction process. Many finely packed particles can be found, indicating that the deep binding of the active components to the TiO2 support has a certain dispersibility. It can be observed that the Pt, O, and Ti of the two catalysts are uniformly distributed, with no evident aggregation, which further verifies that Pt has been successfully loaded onto the TiO2 support (Fig. 6d-f and Fig. 6j-l). At the same time, it can be observed that the Pt element is uniformly distributed and the dispersion degree is high, which further verifies that one of the reasons why the Pt diffraction peak is not significantly observed on the XRD characterization map of the catalyst is that the Pt element is well dispersed. The dispersion of Pt on support helps to more uniform distribution of the active sites to optimize catalyst performance. This, in turn, increases the efficiency of CB oxidation, thereby improving the overall catalytic performance. The topography of the metal particles in the two samples was further analyzed by TEM (Fig. 7 ). No significant particle sensation of Pt particles was observed from Fig. 7a and Fig. 7c. In Fig. 7b and d, it can be seen that Ti particles have clear lattice fringes, corresponding to the (101) plane of anatase TiO2 [33], indicating that the morphology of TiO2 remains unchanged after the reduction process. The Pt in the 0.5 Pt-Ti sample is PtO2, and it can be seen that the Pt component is small in size and evenly dispersed, so the diffraction peak of the Pt particles is not visible on the XRD (Fig. 7b). Concurrently, as depicted in Fig. 7d, a reduction in the particle size of Pt in comparison to the 0.5Pt-Ti sample is evident. This observation suggests that the incorporation of organic acids is advantageous for decreasing the dimensions of the active constituents and improving their dispersion on the support surface. Organic acids play a role in restricting the size of Pt particles, thereby enabling the complete exposure of Pt active sites and consequently offering a greater number of potential CB catalytic oxidation sites. Table 1 shows the results of the specific surface area and pore size of the two catalysts. It can be observed that compared with the 0.5Pt-AT catalyst, the pore size of the 0.5Pt-Ti-TA catalyst is significantly increased. The improved porosity enhances the exposure of Pt nanoparticles to reactants, possibly enhancing the overall efficiency of the material. The SBET and pore volume remain basically unchanged, which may be because in the preparation of the 0.5Pt-Ti-TA catalyst, the chelating agent can assist TiO2 to better play the role of template, enhance the interaction between COO- and Pt in tartaric acid, and generate smaller Pt nanoparticles after calcination of the sample. This can be confirmed by the shift of characteristic peaks to low wavenumbers in Raman spectra (Fig. 9b). When these fine Pt particles enter the pores, they accumulate or even block the pores, thereby increasing the larger pore size and appropriate SBET are helpful to disperse the Pt and improve the catalytic efficiency and selectivity. The above 0.5Pt-Ti-TA catalyst also strongly confirmed the oxidation performance of CB. The BET surface area is directly linked to the CB oxidation of Pt-based systems (Fig. 8 ). Catalysts with larger surface areas and improved pore structures show higher conversion rates of CB due to the availability of more active sites and better reactant diffusion. Numerous studies have proved that catalysts with higher BET surface areas exhibit enhanced oxidation activity, lower activation energies, and improved stability under reaction conditions. According to the IUPAC classification, the two samples showed a typical type IV isotherm of the H3 hysteresis loop [34], indicating that the two samples were mesoporous, and the isotherm also showed that the addition of chelating agent did not change the pore structure of the catalyst. In the range of 0.7–1.0 relative pressures, capillary condensation reactions occur, indicating that the pore size distribution of the catalyst is wide. The BJH pore size distributions of the two catalysts were further analyzed (Table 1). It can be found that the appropriate pore size is conducive to the efficient conversion of CB. 3.3 Reduction characteristics and surface element analysis of Pt catalysts To explore the interaction between the organic acids and the catalysts, the catalysts were analyzed by H2-TPR spectroscopy (Fig. 9 a). It can be observed that the 0.5Pt-Ti-TA catalyst has a unique H2 consumption peak at 100 °C, which may be caused by the fact that the baseline is not flattened during the test, or it may be that the addition of tartaric acid changes the structure of the catalyst and affects its reduction characteristics, so that the catalyst can react with H2 at room temperature and pressure [35]. The characteristic peak of Ti-O bond was analyzed by Raman analysis (Fig. 9b). The 144 cm⁻¹ (Eg) characteristic peak of anatase TiO2 in 0.5 Pt-Ti-TA catalyst shifted to the lower wave number, indicating that the bond energy of Ti-O bond was weakened. It may be that the addition of tartaric acid promotes the interaction between Pt and TiO2, resulting in the activation of Ti-O bonds around Pt and an increase in the number of reactive oxygen species, and the increase in the adsorption capacity of hydrogen [36], which further improved the reaction performance of the catalyst. At the same time, a wide and large reduction peak appeared at about 310 °C, which corresponds to the reduction of part of TiO2, and in the high temperature region of 400 ∼ 600 °C, the 0.5 Pt-Ti-TA consumes more hydrogen than the 0.5 Pt-Ti catalyst. It can be inferred that the redox performance of TA modification materials has been significantly improved due to the size effect. To further investigate the conversion mechanism of CB in samples prepared using organic acid-assisted catalysts, XPS was employed to analyze the surface elements of the catalysts, and the valence information of the surface species was also determined through XPS analysis (Fig. 10 ). For 0.5 Pt-Ti and 0.5 Pt-Ti-TA (Fig. 10a), it can be seen that the main components of the two samples are O, Ti, which is consistent with the TEM analysis. The spectra of O 1 s can be deconvoluted into two peaks, 529.5 eV and 530.9 eV [16], corresponding to the lattice oxygen species (Olatt) and adsorbed oxygen species (Oads) of Ti-O-Ti, respectively (Fig. 10b). In addition, details of the surface composition and local atomic environment of the 0.5Pt-Ti and 0.5Pt-Ti-TA catalysts were obtained by XPS measurements. The XPS results for the 0.5Pt-Ti and 0.5Pt-Ti-TA catalysts are summarized in Table 2 . It can be inferred that the incorporation of tartaric acid is beneficial for the formation of abundant oxygen vacancies in the 0.5Pt-Ti-TA sample, thereby increasing the likelihood of generating active adsorbed oxygen species at the defect sites. The Ti 2p XPS spectrum is shown in Fig. 10c, and the binding energies of 458.3 eV and 463.9 eV belong to the Ti4+ species in the 2p 3/2 and 2p 1/2 orbitals [32], indicating that the preparation of organic acid-assisted catalysts did not cause a change in the valence state of Ti4+ species on the surface of the TiO2 support material. Two peaks (Pt 4f 7/2 and Pt 4f 5/2) at 71.3 eV and 74.0 eV [37] were observed in the Pt 4f XPS spectrum shown in Fig. 10d, and Pt0 accounted for 20.47 % in the 0.5Pt-Ti catalyst, but 6.40 % in the 0.5Pt-Ti-TA catalyst, indicating that the addition of tartaric acid was conducive to the formation of complexes. The properties of the catalyst changed, resulting in the generation of more Pt4+. In summary, XPS characterization showed that Pt and Ti had both high valence and metallic states in the catalyst, indicating that the catalyst may have strong interactions during the reduction process, and did not reduce all Pt oxides to metallic states [18]. Among them, the 0.5Pt-Ti-TA sample had more abundant adsorbed oxygen species, which helps to promote the electron transfer of Pt0 to TiO2, thereby stimulating the activity of Pt and facilitating the oxidation process of adsorptive CB on the carrier surface. FTIR analyses were performed before and after the 0.5Pt-Ti and 0.5Pt-Ti-TA reactions (Fig. S5). It can be seen that the structure of the sample with and without organic acids is largely unchanged before and after the reaction. The change of water peak intensity was detected at 3339 cm-1 [38], which may be caused by partial accumulation of water molecules generated by CB oxidation. The peak at 1634.0 cm-1 is attributed to the bending vibration of the material surface physically absorbing water. In addition, no characteristic band corresponding to tartaric acid was found in the figure, which may be that the structure of tartaric acid was completely destroyed during calcination. By analyzing the surface elements of used catalysts (Fig. 11 ), it is found that Pt0 and Pt4+ exist in the used 0.5Pt-Ti-TA catalyst, while only Pt4+ exists in the 0.5Pt-Ti catalyst, which may be due to the participation of Pt0 in the activation process of adsorptive oxygen, leading to the transformation of Pt0 to Pt4+. In addition, Pt acts as the active center during chlorobenzene oxidation, which may lead to the oxidation of Pt by providing electrons to participate in the reaction. For the reduction of Olatt/Oads ratio, it may be that Olatt directly participates in the oxidation process of chlorobenzene, generating CO₂ and H₂O, resulting in the reduction of lattice oxygen, adsorbed oxygen complements the surface oxygen vacancy and further participates in the reaction, and gaseous oxygen promotes the continuous oxidation process by replenishing adsorbed oxygen. 3.4 Mechanism of VOCs catalytic oxidation The possible microscopic mechanism of CB oxidation catalyzed by 0.5Pt-Ti-TA was speculated (Fig. 12 ). The adsorption/active site on the carrier preferentially adsorbs CB molecules and activates molecular oxygen, and then the active Pt species dispersed by organic acids perform ring-opening reaction on CB. The presence of Pt4+ on the surface promotes the ring-opening reaction and deep oxidation process of CB. In addition, the highly dispersed Pt species and rapid desorption of products ensure recycling of the active site (Fig. S7). Through effective protection of Pt sites and low temperature reducibility, organic acid strategy achieved improved chlorine toxicity resistance and stable catalytic activity. 4 Conclusion In summary, a series of 0.5 Pt-Ti catalysts were prepared for CB catalytic oxidation by adjusting the interfacial stability and dispersibility of the carrier and Pt through the organic acid strategy in this study. The introduction of tartaric acid effectively improved the surface reduction property of 0.5Pt-Ti-TA, and the presence of high-valence Pt on the catalyst surface also significantly improved the low temperature catalytic stability of CB. In addition, tartaric acid can be strongly coordinated with Ti center to form a stable titanium-containing complex, which improves the dispersion of platinum, prevents the agglomeration of particles, and makes the active site distribution more uniform. The CB oxidation stability and water resistance of 0.5Pt-Ti-TA catalyst at 300℃ further confirm the results of the low temperature stability improvement. coredata.dc:description: The Pt-based catalyst for purifying chlorinated volatile organic compounds (Cl-VOCs) has the advantages of high catalytic efficiency and low ignition temperature, but the problem of poor resistance to chlorine and water poisoning has not been effectively solved. A series of 0.5 Pt-Ti catalysts were prepared for chlorobenzene (CB) catalytic oxidation by adjusting the interfacial stability and dispersibility of the TiO2 and Pt through the organic acid strategy in this study. The introduction of tartaric acid (TA) effectively enhanced the surface reduction performance of 0.5Pt-Ti-TA and the proportion of Pt4+ on the surface. In addition, TA can strongly coordinate with Ti center to form stable titanium-containing complexes, improve the dispersion of Pt, prevent particles from agglomerating, and make the distribution of active sites more uniform. The designed 0.5Pt-Ti-TA exhibits excellent chlorine and water resistance at 300℃ (5 %H2O, 500 ppm CB), and has a higher potential of application.
